title: Johnson & Johnson ordered to pay £6.6bn to man who grew breasts
text:
Johnson & Johnson has been ordered to pay £6.6bn damages to a man who grew breasts

American giant Johnson & Johnson faces a flood of claims after it was ordered to pay £6.6billion damages to a man who grew breasts after taking an antipsychotic drug.

The staggering award was made by a jury after Nicholas Murray argued he was not sufficiently warned about the side effects of risperdal, used to treat symptoms of schizophrenia, bipolar disorder and autism.

He had been handed more than £550,000 by a judge, with the extra sum ordered as part of 'punitive damages'.

Analysts branded the damages 'disproportionate' and expect it to be overturned or cut.

But it was another costly setback ford drugs firm Johnson & Johnson, which is battling separate damages claims worth billions of dollars over the opioid crisis.

Murray, 26, was prescribed risperdal at the age of nine to fight sleep problems related to his autism.

But he was later taken off it when he realised his breasts were growing, something his lawyers claim was caused by the drug causing a hormone imbalance.

In the case in Philadelphia, Johnson & Johnson was accused of not making risks associated with risperdal clear to doctors prescribing the drug and their patients.

The company faces similar claims from around 13,400 other people.
